result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

BY THE COURT:  Bond continued.

Prosecuting attorney Kelly A Cassidy appeared in court for the State of Wisconsin, Defendant Eric G. Severson appeared in court, in custody, Attorney Oren Jakobson for Eric G. Severson appeared in court.

State has complied with victim notification statutes.
There are no victims that wish to make a statement.

3:42 PM J.M. is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Cassidy.
Witness identifies Defendant.
3:49 PM Cross examination by Atty Jakobson.
3:56 PM Re-direct by Atty Cassidy.
Witness describes where Defendant is seated.

State has nothing further to present.
Atty Jakobson has nothing to present.

Neither party wish to make final statements.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds probable cause does exist in the case.

Court states the findings, for the record.
940.19(2) is referred to.
